revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2013}} {{Use British English|date=April 2012}} {{infobox person |name=Natalie Haynes |image=Natalie Haynes at QEDcon 2013.jpg |birth_date=1974 |birth_place=[[Birmingham]] }} '''Natalie Louise Haynes''' (born 1974 in [[Birmingham]])<ref name="The Herald 15 March 2014">{{cite news | title= The classics have a role to play in Natalie Haynes's debut thriller|url= http://www.heraldscotland.com/arts_ents/13150619.The_classics_have_a_role_to_play_in_Natalie_Haynes_s_debut_thriller/| author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->|date= 15 March 2014| work= [[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]]| publisher= Herald & Times Group| accessdate= 3 December 2017 }}</ref> is an English writer and broadcaster and a former comedian. She attended [[King Edward VI High School for Girls, Birmingham]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kehs.org.uk/newsDetails/284/0|title=Awards Evening 2010:Old Edwardian Natalie Haynes presented awards to last year's U6 at the Awards Evening on Friday 12th November|publisher=King Edward VI High School for Girls|accessdate=26 March 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120120230917/http://www.kehs.org.uk/newsDetails/284/0|archivedate=20 January 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> then read [[Classics]] at [[Christ's College, Cambridge]], and was also a member of [[Cambridge University Footlights Dramatic Club]].
==Radio==
Haynes has been a panellist on ''[[Wordaholics]]'', ''We've Been Here Before'', ''[[Banter (radio show)|Banter]]'', ''[[Quote... Unquote]]'', ''Personality Test'', and ''[[Armando Iannucci's Charm Offensive]]'' on [[BBC Radio 4]]. She has contributed to [[BBC 7]] comedy review show ''[[Serious About Comedy]]'' and reviews films for ''[[Front Row (radio)|Front Row]]''.
Her stand-up featured on ''Front Row'' and ''[[Loose Ends (radio)|Loose Ends]]'' on BBC Radio 4, and on [[BBC 7]]'s ''Spanking New''. She has also appeared in the BBC Radio 4 ''Pick of the [[Edinburgh Fringe|Fringe]]'' in 2004 and 2005. She has also appeared on [[Radio Five Live]]'s [[Anita Anand]] Show, and ''[[MacAulay and Co.]]'' on [[BBC Scotland]].
In 2005 and 2006 Haynes wrote and presented documentaries on comic writers, for BBC Radio 4; modern female writers including [[Jessica Mitford]] and [[Dorothy Parker]], and [[Aristophanes]], [[Juvenal]] and [[Martial]].
She appears as a critic on ''[[Saturday Review (radio)|Saturday Review]]'' on BBC Radio 4.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b006qh6g|title=Saturday Review - BBC Radio 4|author=|date=|website=BBC|accessdate=2 April 2018}}</ref>
On 4 February 2013 she was the feature of the BBC Radio 4 programme ''With Great Pleasure''. Her guests included novellist [[Julian Barnes]], who read from one of his own books.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b01qdtq0|title=Natalie Haynes, With Great Pleasure - BBC Radio 4|author=|date=|website=BBC|accessdate=2 April 2018}}</ref>
On BBC Radio 4 "Natalie Haynes Stands up for the Classics" Three series in which she chooses people to make serious and amusing remarks about the good and the great from Greece and Rome from Petronius to Sappho . <ref>{{citeweb|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b077x8pc|title=Natalie Haynes Stands Up for the Classics - BBC Radio 4|author=|date=|website=BBC|accessdate=2 April 2018}}</ref>
==Television==
Haynes was a regular panellist on BBC's ''[[The Review Show]]'' and was the most-booked guest on [[More4]]'s ''The Last Word''. She appeared as a panellist on BBC 4's ''[[The Book Quiz]]'', and on their Poetry Special alongside [[Andrew Motion]] and [[George Szirtes]]. She also appeared on ''Backlash'', a BBC2 documentary on voluntary childlessness, wrote and performed in the STV/Assembly Television ''Best of the Fest'' in August 2005. Haynes has been a panellist on [[BBC Four]]'s quiz show ''Mindgames'', featured on ''Must Try Harder'' on [[BBC Two]] in 2006 and was the art and literature expert on the BBC Two quiz show ''Knowitalls''.
In August 2007, she appeared on BBC Four's ''[[The Book Quiz]]'' hosted by [[David Baddiel]].<ref name="BBC Book Quiz 2007">{{cite episode| title= The Book Quiz: Series 1, Episode 3 of 5| series= [[The Book Quiz]]| credits= Presenter: [[David Baddiel]]; Competitors: [[Jon Ronson]], Natalie Haynes, [[Lionel Shriver]], [[Mark Thomas]]| network= BBC| station= [[BBC Four]]| url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b007vbjs| airdate= 31 July 2007| accessdate= 28 January 2018 }}</ref> On the programme she admitted researching a book on Wikipedia in order to bluff having read it.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/bbcfour/listings/programme.shtml?filename=20070802/20070802_2200_4544_21829_30&day=today&service_id=4544 BBC – BBC Four Listings – Programmes<!-- Bot generated title -->]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
In April 2008 Haynes was a member of stand-up comedians team on ''[[University Challenge|University Challenge: The Professionals]]''.<ref name="BBC University Challenge - The Professionals">{{cite episode| title= University Challenge - The Professionals: Episode 2: 2008| series= [[University Challenge#Spin-off shows| University Challenge - The Professionals]]| credits= Presenter: [[Jeremy Paxman]]| network= BBC| station= [[BBC Two]]| url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b009rjhl| airdate= 1 April 2008| accessdate= 28 January 2018 }}</ref> Her team lost to the [[Ministry of Justice (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Justice]], 100 points to 215. In November 2009 she appeared on [[BBC One]]'s ''[[Question Time (TV series)|Question Time]]''.<ref name="BBC Question Time 2009">{{cite episode| title= Question Time: 05/11/2009| series= [[Question Time (TV series)|Question Time]]| credits= Presenter: [[David Dimbleby]]; Participants: [[Peter Hain]], [[Nick Herbert]], Natalie Haynes; Executive Producer: Steve Anderson| network= BBC| station= [[BBC One]] (except Wales)| url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00nqcq7| airdate= 5 November 2009| accessdate= 28 January 2018 }}</ref>
==Journalism==
Haynes has been a Guest Contributor for ''[[The Times]]'' since October 2006, and a regular contributor to ''[[New Humanist]]''. She has also written for ''[[The Sunday Times]] Magazine'', ''[[The Sunday Telegraph]]'', ''[[The Big Issue]]'', ''[[Loaded (magazine)|Loaded]]'', and ''[[The Independent]]''.
==Live shows==
Haynes has toured from Dublin and Berlin to Manhattan – and has performed five [[Edinburgh Fringe]] sell-out runs and national tours. She was nominated for the Best Newcomer Award at the 2002 [[Edinburgh Comedy Awards|Perrier Comedy Awards]],<ref name="Edinburgh Comedy Awards 2002">{{cite web | title= Edinburgh Comedy Awards: Best Newcomer: 2002|url= http://www.comedyawards.co.uk/best-newcomer| author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->|date= | website= comedyawards.co.uk | publisher= [[Edinburgh Comedy Awards]]| accessdate= 3 December 2017 }}</ref> the first woman to receive this nomination.<ref name="Guardian 16 August 2017">{{cite news |last= Logan |first= Brian| authorlink= |title= Standups on why they quit comedy: 'I have nightmares about having to do it again' |url= https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2017/aug/16/standups-quit-comedy-edinburgh-hannah-gadbsy| date= 16 August 2017 |newspaper= [[The Guardian]] |location=London| accessdate=3 December 2017 }}</ref>
* 2002 ''Six Degrees of Desolation'' (nominated for Perrier Award Best Newcomer) * 2003 ''Troubled Enough'' * 2004 ''Still Not Sorry'' * 2005 ''Run Or Die'' * 2006 ''Watching the Detectives''
Haynes is the only comedian to have appeared at every [[Newbury Comedy Festival]].
==Books== Haynes has written a non-fiction book, ''The Ancient Guide To Modern Life'', on the subject of how living well in the present requires some recourse to the ancient world. It was published by Profile Books in November 2010.
Her first children's novel, ''The Great Escape'', was published by Simon & Schuster in September 2007. It won a [[PETA]] [[Proggy award]], for best animal-friendly children's book, in 2008.
Haynes' debut novel ''Amber Fury'' (titled ''The Furies'' in the U. S.) was released in 2014. Her second novel ''Children of Jocasta'', a retelling of [[Antigone (Sophocles play)|Antigone]] and [[Oedipus Rex]], was released in 2017.<ref>{{cite web | title = The Children of Jocasta | url = https://www.panmacmillan.com/authors/natalie-haynes/the-children-of-jocasta | author = <!--Not stated--> | website = Pan Macmillan | date = 5 April 2017 | accessdate = 16 May 2017}}</ref>
Haynes' contributed an essay to ''Serenity Found'', a book about [[Joss Whedon]]'s television show ''[[Firefly (TV series)|Firefly]]'', edited by [[Jane Espenson]], which was published in 2007 by BenBella Books. Her entries on subjects from [[Agatha Christie]] to [[E. F. Benson|E.F. Benson]] can be found in Cassell's ''[[Little Black Book of Books]]'', published in 2007.
